Package org.firstinspires.ftc.teamcode.pedroPathing.follower

Class DriveVectorScaler

java.lang.Object
org.firstinspires.ftc.teamcode.pedroPathing.follower.DriveVectorScaler
public class DriveVectorScaler extends Object
This is the DriveVectorScaler class. This class takes in inputs Vectors for driving, heading correction, and translational/centripetal correction and returns an array with wheel powers.

  • Constructor Summary

    Constructors
    Constructor
    Description
    DriveVectorScaler(Vector frontLeftVector)
    This creates a new DriveVectorScaler, which takes in various movement vectors and outputs the wheel drive powers necessary to move in the intended direction, given the true movement vector for the front left mecanum wheel.

  • Method Summary

    Modifier and Type
    Method
    Description
    double
    findNormalizingScaling(Vector staticVector, Vector variableVector)
    This takes in two Vectors, one static and one variable, and returns the scaling factor that, when multiplied to the variable Vector, results in magnitude of the sum of the static Vector and the scaled variable Vector being 1.
    double[]
    getDrivePowers(Vector correctivePower, Vector headingPower, Vector pathingPower, double robotHeading)
    This takes in vectors for corrective power, heading power, and pathing power and outputs an Array of four doubles, one for each wheel's motor power.

  • Constructor Details

    • DriveVectorScaler

      public DriveVectorScaler(Vector frontLeftVector)
      This creates a new DriveVectorScaler, which takes in various movement vectors and outputs the wheel drive powers necessary to move in the intended direction, given the true movement vector for the front left mecanum wheel.
      Parameters:
      frontLeftVector - this is the front left mecanum wheel's preferred drive vector.

  • Method Details

    • getDrivePowers

      public double[] getDrivePowers(Vector correctivePower, Vector headingPower, Vector pathingPower, double robotHeading)
      This takes in vectors for corrective power, heading power, and pathing power and outputs an Array of four doubles, one for each wheel's motor power. IMPORTANT NOTE: all vector inputs are clamped between 0 and 1 inclusive in magnitude.
      Parameters:
      correctivePower - this Vector includes the centrifugal force scaling Vector as well as a translational power Vector to correct onto the Bezier curve the Follower is following.
      headingPower - this Vector points in the direction of the robot's current heaing, and the magnitude tells the robot how much it should turn and in which direction.
      pathingPower - this Vector points in the direction the robot needs to go to continue along the Path.
      robotHeading - this is the current heading of the robot, which is used to calculate how much power to allocate to each wheel.
      Returns:
      this returns an Array of doubles with a length of 4, which contains the wheel powers.

    • findNormalizingScaling

      public double findNormalizingScaling(Vector staticVector, Vector variableVector)
      This takes in two Vectors, one static and one variable, and returns the scaling factor that, when multiplied to the variable Vector, results in magnitude of the sum of the static Vector and the scaled variable Vector being 1. IMPORTANT NOTE: I did not intend for this to be used for anything other than the method above this one in this class, so there will be errors if you input Vectors of length greater than 1, and it will scale up the variable Vector if the magnitude of the sum of the two input Vectors isn't greater than 1. So, just don't use this elsewhere. There's gotta be a better way to do whatever you're trying to do. I know that this is used outside of this class, however, I created this method so I get to use it if I want to. Also, it's only used once outside of the DriveVectorScaler class, and it's used to scale Vectors, as intended.
      Parameters:
      staticVector - the Vector that is held constant.
      variableVector - the Vector getting scaled to make the sum of the input Vectors have a magnitude of 1.
      Returns:
      returns the scaling factor for the variable Vector.
